article.title: Brassinosteroids Inhibit Autotropic Root Straightening by Modifying Filamentous-Actin Organization and Dynamics
funding: National Aeronautics and Space Administration grants 80NSSC18K1462 and 80NSSC19KO129
article.abstract: When positioned horizontally, roots grow down toward the direction of gravity. This phenomenon, called gravitropism, is influenced by most of the major plant hormones including brassinosteroids. Epi-brassinolide (eBL) was previously shown to enhance root gravitropism, a phenomenon similar to the response of roots exposed to the actin inhibitor, latrunculin B (LatB). This led us to hypothesize that eBL might enhance root gravitropism through its effects on filamentous-actin (F-actin).

sections.introduction: Plants are sessile organisms that are limited by their location. As such, they have evolved sensitive and delicate ways to respond to environmental cues allowing them to reprogram their growth when presented with changes in their surroundings.
sections.methods: Maize (Zea mays L. cultivar Merit) seeds were soaked for 10 to 12 h in deionized water.
sections.results: Previous reports have shown that LatB and eBL promoted gravitropism in roots.
sections.discussion: In this paper, a slowly-rotating 2-D clinostat was used to gain additional insights into actin-mediated regulation of directional root growth.

article.insights_summary: Brassinosteroids inhibit autotropic root straightening by modifying filamentous-actin organization and dynamics. This conclusion was based on the observation that exogenous application of eBL and LatB triggered similar enhanced root gravitropism and amplified root coiling on a clinostat.
